awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will apply tropical geometry techniques to resolving long-standing problems in combinatorics and diophantine geometry. Tropical geometry is a method for transforming questions in algebraic geometry, which is the study of polynomial systems of equations, into questions in combinatorics, which is the mathematics of discrete structures. The combinatorial problems addressed involve understanding the counts of certain discrete geometric objects. Diophantine geometry is the study of rational solutions to polynomial systems. By degenerating the polynomial systems according to combinatorics, one can bound the number of solutions. The PI will engage in educational and outreach activities including the following: the broadening of his department's honors program; community outreach presentations; mentorship of students from underrepresented groups; graduate advising; and exposition.

The research in this project focuses on open problems in combinatorics and diophantine geometry. With collaborators, the PI will incorporate algebraic geometric methods (particularly Hodge theory, positivity, and genericity) into geometric combinatorics with the goal of understanding the possible face numbers of certain polyhedral complexes. By refining established techniques, he will investigate sharper inequalities among face number which will elucidate combinatorial structures. He will also deepen the commutative algebraic underpinnings of his recent work on matroids. In Diophantine geometry, he will study bounds on the number of rational and torsion points on curves. Following the methods of Buium and Kim, with collaborators, he will examine functions on curves of bad reduction that vanish on points of arithmetic interest and bound their zeroes. This involves elaborating analogies between classical and p-adic analytic geometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Following the PI’s original proposal, the PI has applied techniques from tropical geometry to problems in combinatorics and Diophantine geometry. Tropical geometry is a method for transforming questions in algebraic geometry, which is the study of polynomial systems of equations, into questions in about discrete structures. This leads to deep analogies and strong combinatorial constraints.

  Much of the PI’s research has involved p-adic integration, a major tool for identifying and bounding rational and torsion points on curves. In joint work with Daniel Litt, the PI has developed the foundations of p-adic iterated integrals in terms of filtrations on the fundamental group of an algebraic curve. This made use of the theory of combinatorial iterated integrals as developed with Raymond Cheng, a project that began as undergraduate research. With Enis Kaya, he has developed algorithms for performing p-adic integrals on bad reduction curves.

  Informed by the above work, the PI, with his graduate student Kyle Binder, developed a theory of the tropical unipotent fundamental group and proved that under certain conditions, it computes the pro-unipotent completion of the fundamental group of an algebraic variety.

  The PI has done work in algebraic combinatorics. With postdoc Max Kutler, he made a systematic study of matroidal mixed Eulerian number, a research direction initiated in the work of Berget–Spink–Tseng. He has also done work with postdoc McCabe Olsen on q-analogues.

  The PI taught a graduate course on the resolution of the Rota--Heron--Welsh log-concavity conjecture and has written lecture notes that have been revised and distributed to interested researchers.

   The PI has developed an honors Foundations of Higher Mathematics class aimed at strong students transitioning from problem-oriented introductory classes to rigorous proof-based classes. The PI has written substantial lecture notes for this class that have since been used by other instructors.

  The PI is an organizer for the KOALA, the Workshop of the Kentucky--Ohio Algebra Alliance which alternates between the University of Kentucky and the Ohio State University and the KOI (Kentucky-Ohio-Indiana) Combinatorics Lectures which alternates between the University of Kentucky, the Ohio State University, and Indiana University. He was the principal organizer of the KOI Combinatorics Lectures meeting held in Fall 2023 at the Ohio State University.
